data.title: StumbleUpon to eBay: So long and thanks for all the hits
data.meta_description: Two years after eBay bought web discovery service StumbleUpon for $75m, its founders have bought it back and returned to startup mode
data.text:
When is a startup not a startup? When it's got something to do with eBay, as far as I can tell.

The question isn't some kind of Zen riddle, but my immediate reaction to the news that StumbleUpon and eBay were parting ways - just two years after the auction giant sloshed $75m on buying the web discovery service. The deal initially resulted in plenty of head-scratching action, but since the buyout the service appeared to plod on well enough.

But today the companies have announced that co-founders Garrett Camp and Geoff Smith - along with a team of investors - have bought SU back. Meaning, I suppose, that it's a startup again. An official entry on the StumbleUpon blog suggests eBay had a lack of ambition, saying that "our goal is to make StumbleUpon the web's largest recommendation engine and we think this is the best way to get us there".

It still leaves a big question about where StumbleUpon goes in the future - after all, if venture-backed startups have two ways to rake in cash (the stock market and acquisition) then who's going to take on eBay's sloppy seconds?
